mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Mount Pierce?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Mount Pierce take 3-5 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 6.4 miles with Moderate difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Mount Pierce hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Mount Pierce is rated Moderate. At 4,312 feet, expect challenging terrain above treeline with potential for rapid weather changes. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Mount Pierce?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Mount Pierce. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Mount Pierce?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Crawford Path to Pierce, offering Shortest route to a 4000-footer via America's oldest hiking trail..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Mount Pierce?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Mount Pierce is late May through October. Summer and fall offer the best conditions, though expect crowds on weekends. Winter hiking requires specialized gear and experience.

page_content.description:
At 4,312 feet, Mount Pierce ranks among New Hampshire's celebrated 4000-Footersa collection of 48 peaks that challenge and inspire hikers throughout the Northeast. This moderate summit offers a quintessential White Mountain experience.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Crawford Path to Pierce**, covers 6.4 miles and is rated Moderate. Shortest route to a 4000-footer via America's oldest hiking trail.

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** Mount Eisenhower lies just 1.2 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.conditions: Muddy trails, snow above 3000ft until May
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.conditions: Peak foliage late Sept, early snow possible in October
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.conditions: Full winter conditions, extreme cold and wind above treeline
winter.tips: Winter hiking requires specialized skills and gear. Never hike alone. Check avalanche conditions for steeper terrain.
